events.target_title: [IMAPx] Use extended LIST with Cyrus IMAP >= 2.5.11

note.body:
cc5206fa broke communicating with my university's Cyrus instance, I think.
It had the serverinfo announcement turned off and thus only announced `OK [CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 LITERAL+ ID ENABLE MUPDATE=mupdate://mupdate.urz.uni-magdeburg.de/ AUTH=GSS-SPNEGO AUTH=GSSAPI AUTH=LOGIN AUTH=PLAIN SASL-IR] cyrus3.ovgu.de server ready`.
This way, my s/o's Evolution 3.26.1 (on Ubuntu 17.10) still turned off the LIST-EXTENDED extension while my 3.28.5 (on Fedora 28) never suspected the server to mess this up and showed all kinds of problems.
Anyway, I convinced the admin to enable the serverinfo announcement and it turns out that it is a 2.5.11 server!
Nonetheless, after enabling the serverinfo, my Evolution disabled the LIST-EXTENDED extension, too, and the problems, naturally, disappeared.
After digging into the source code, I noticed that to get to the version string, exactly two words were skipped, and the comments implied that those were always “Cyrus” and “IMAP”.
My university's server now announces `OK [CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 LITERAL+ ID ENABLE MUPDATE=mupdate://mupdate.urz.uni-magdeburg.de/ AUTH=GSS-SPNEGO AUTH=GSSAPI AUTH=LOGIN AUTH=PLAIN SASL-IR] cyrus3.ovgu.de Cyrus IMAP Murder 2.5.12 server ready`, introducing another word, “[Murder](https://www.cyrusimap.org/imap/reference/admin/murder/murder.html)”, preventing Evolution to get to the version string and proceed with LIST-EXTENDED enabled.
I set out to enable Evolution to skip the word “Murder”, as well, in case it existed and the results can be seen [here (3.28)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/TpmKranz/evolution-data-server/commit/8cf0ae3c1b29bf32f4e27ed66e1ae207d5b681bb) or [here (3.30)](https://gitlab.gnome.org/TpmKranz/evolution-data-server/commit/5fe7384c6e484f51e3d7057c85f01765ae12da86).
Now, Evolution correctly identifies the Cyrus server's version to be 2.5.11, doesn't disable the extension and **problems occur**.

So was skipping “Cyrus” and “IMAP” but never “Murder” intentional since it's an entirely different product or was it an oversight and something else is wrong with my university's Cyrus instance?

events.target_title: [IMAPx] Use extended LIST with Cyrus IMAP >= 2.5.11

note.body:
I'm sorry, I didn't notice that they updated in the meantime; when I reported the problem to them a few days ago and the serverinfo got enabled, the version was still 2.5.11.
Unfortunately that doesn't change the fact that once it is recognized as a “non-broken” Cyrus, i.e. of version ≥2.5.11, the INBOX directory doesn't work correctly anymore.

At all times, the “Folder subscriptions” window is empty:

![image](/uploads/46a13270f2b1c75a6012e8a1afacd224/image.png)

It also shows the following error message:

![image](/uploads/b31c127867d950a7290542d0729d4ae6/image.png)

Sometimes the INBOX and its subfolders just completely disappear from my account/directory tree in the left-hand panel:

![image](/uploads/5d3c473b883bab5908b6f4ac01829293/image.png)

This is accompanied by the following error message:

![image](/uploads/7d47b3fd1be700f3c3e7c0dd6a5fabf9/image.png)

Based on these observations, I'd say that LIST-EXTENDED is still broken with that server.

All this happens only **with** my changes enabled, which allow Evolution to extract the version number despite the additional word “Murder” in the greeting (the first occurence of “cyrus” is skipped anyway because it isn't followed by a space).

With an unmodified eds 3.28.5, version detection chokes on “Murder” (`sscanf` scans zero arguments [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/gnome-3-28/src/camel/providers/imapx/camel-imapx-server.c#L1895)) and sets the version to 0.0.0 [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/gnome-3-28/src/camel/providers/imapx/camel-imapx-server.c#L1900), after which no more occurence of “cyrus” can be found (setting `pp = NULL`) [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/blob/gnome-3-28/src/camel/providers/imapx/camel-imapx-server.c#L1905) and the loop ends, making `imapx_server_check_is_broken_cyrus` return `true`.
This circumvents the use of LIST-EXTENDED and everything works as one would expect if one never heard of that extension, which I didn't.
I also don't know what it does and how I can test its proper use; I just see the broken behaviour mentioned above.

Anyway, with the unmodified eds, the “Folder subscriptions” window looks like this:

![image](/uploads/e0c4e9edfd5c93a1f60d363f9ee7bba9/image.png)

The fact that my university's Cyrus server is recognized as broken despite it being on version 2.5.12 *and* that it actually *is* broken seems to me like a big coincidence and I'd be happy to know whether or not it is.

WIP: ES6 Modules

note.body:
Hi, I've been researching stuff related to ESM with my work on [webrun](https://github.com/RangerMauve/webrun) lately and I recently saw GJS and was really excited by the prospect of having another environment to use ESM with.

After looking at the various tradeoffs and playing aroudn with it in node, I'm found that I'm very much against the prospect of using `.mjs`. The file extension doesn't work on the web, it's confusing to new developers and text editors, and it just feels like a dirty hack.

I really like the idea of using the `-m` flag to opt-into loading code as ESM. It lets people use the new feature without breaking existing code.

Regarding `import`ing modules from a script context, I think that it'd be best to wait for SpiderMonkey to get the new [dynamic import](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-dynamic-import) syntax and then integrating with that instead of hacking around it. Progress for that in SpiderMonkey is [here](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1342012).

Modules and scripts have very different semantics so I'd imagine it would be confusing for newbies. That way you can separate the two where scripts would need to use `await import("whatever")` in order to load something from ESM, and ESM would only `import from` other ESM modules.

In my webrun project I've kinda cheated for the REPL (which runs in a script context) by adding a `_import` global and transforming the source to rewrite calls to `import()` to `_import()`. This works well as it lets me use the new dynamic import semantics without waiting for Node to enable it, but it feels a little hacky. 

I also believe that it's important to enable people to plug into the resolution process in the loader since that will allow for experimentation with different protocols and methods of loading.

Node.js took a crack at it with the [loader API](https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html), but I think they did an even better job with new [vm.SourceTextModule](https://nodejs.org/api/vm.html#vm_class_vm_sourcetextmodule) API since it's super easy to use and iterate upon.

I've been using this to enable support for loading ESM modules through HTTPS which lets me share modules between web browsers and Node. It would be amazing if GJS supported importing from HTTPS since it'd enable even more reuse and help the JS ecosystem standardise on one module system across all environments. No fiddling with NPM and transpilers, just using `import` and knowing that it'll work everywhere.

I'm not very good at CPP, but I was wondering if there was anything I could do to help with this feature.

note.body:
The short answer is that I did not explicitly set this option or any other.  I imported the VPN settings from the service provider.  The more detailed answer is that I see no such option in the "General" tab that you describe.  In this tab I see two options: "All users may connect to this network" (checked) and "Metered connection" (set to "Automatic").

I am wondering whether this question is in fact the path the conversation ought to follow.  The behavior I have observed and explained is what I am inclined to suggest is a design flaw with the way the software handles connections that are configured for automatic connection.  Even if this particular issue does not manifest if automatic connection is disabled, it would still manifest if automatic connection is enabled, which is a normal use case.  That it is possible to disable automatic connection is an issue separate from the question of usability *in the case the option is enabled*.  

Having expressed my concerns, I am open to trying any experiment with my configuration that is helpful for you and feasible for me, as long as I have a sequence of steps that I can follow.

events.target_title: network completely unusable when vpn connect fails

note.body:
It is possible that I have made inaccurate assumptions, and I am happy to address them, but you have raised a great many points, and if I attempt to address them all at the same time, I fear that the communication will become hopelessly convoluted.

Let me begin with two notes:
- The information I have provided about the settings shown in the graphical interface is from the window generated from running `nm-connection-editor` on the command line.
- While I have not explicitly set any option for "Automatically connect", we cannot rule out the possibility that it is configured.  Like I say, the current settings are created by a script provided by the VPN service provider.  Whatever default settings were overridden by the script are likely to remain in the current settings.

Please give your response to these considerations.

I promise I am not ignoring your more serious objections and questions.  I want to be clear on the more mundane questions before moving forward and risking a more serious miscommunication.

> The problems reported by @eblau seems to be because the mount is considerent as system_internal and we don't allow trashing on system_internal mounts currently.

Fine, I wasn't aware of that issue.  Not to beat a dead horse, but without error messages that explain the reason, the user is left uncertain about why trashing fails.  My assumption was that the probable reasons in my case were among the problems I listed, and I regret that I can do no better than to assume. 

Also, some users reported success changing their mount options from root to the target user, which change I did not try myself, but which reports I used to try to understand what GIO might be doing.  In my case,  I wanted trashing to work for any user, not just a designated one.

events.target_title: trash requirements restrictive and inconsistent for non-system mounts

note.body:
And I forgot to mention that listing the trash contents works with the less restrictive criteria.  

Ultimately, I would suggest that checking the permissions and ownership of an existing directory is unhelpful.  Permissions exist to limit who accesses a resource, not who *wants* to access the resource.  If a directory is writable, and you want to write to it, then you should just write to it.

**Edit:**  Another point, and I'm not trying to be pedantic, but I would hope that any changes you choose to make fully consider the actual use cases.  Please consider  that removable storage, network storage, and such, is likely to have the problem of alignment of UIDs.  A USB volume or NAS may be used by many users on many systems.  The mapping of UID to actual user (i.e. individual human being) is not fixed.  With the current scheme, I might  find my colleague's operations are applied to my trash bin, or that I cannot locate a resource for recovery that I personally trashed on a different system.  Or I might want to recover a resource deleted by a friend to whom I had lent my removable media.  You could consider that some volumes would have a shared trash bin, not a separate one for each UID.  I understand   the needs to respect to the specification and  to maintain interoperability, but these issues are worth considering.

events.target_title: All tool buttons are shown as disabled

note.body:
It doesn't depend on the theme. Much more interesting is "Edit > Preferences > Interfaces > Icon Theme", which is set to Symbolic by default.

Choosing another icon theme fixes the problem. But this can only be regarded a workaround. The real problem is that the _default_ icon set looks disabled, which surely confuses lots of users. It is also undistinguishable from the background image above the tools area, which leads to even more confusion.

The default icon set should be Color instead of Symbolic.

events.target_title: Color selector spinbuttons in 0..100 mode need more precision
Color picker should show current pixel color in a tooltip
Color picker should show current pixel color in a tooltip

note.body:
Ah, thanks. It's almost what I want.

For picking a color this works, and it is also discoverable: The Color Picker tool has a properties box, and the last checkbox says "Use info window (Shift)". (I just hadn't seen it before.)

But: Seeing the pixel color only works when I click the mouse button. When only hovering over the image, it does not update the pixel information, which is probably intended, so that unintended mouse movements don't modify the existing information. Therefore my expectation is that the information is updated as long as I hold the shift key. That way, I have three options:

* Without pressing any key, the box continues to show the information from the previous interesting pixel.
* When pressing Shift, the box updates the pixel information.
* When clicking, the color is selected as the new foreground or background color.

The box also doesn't appear when I press the Shift key. I have to press Shift+LeftClick to show it. That is unexpectedly late. If it had been shown as soon as I press Shift alone, I would not have written this issue.

Another thing I don't understand: In the Color Picker properties dialog, the checkbox updates when I press and hold the Shift key. But the information box does not appear or disappear. That is, the state in the checkbox does not correspond to the visibility of the information box. This is confusing.

note.body:
At least amd64 arch is affected by this bug.

events.target_title: Flags validation fails

note.body:
I found the answer. Here's output of sizeof(gulong) and sizeof(guint) for different archs:
```
i686:   long: 4, int: 4
x86_64: long: 8, int: 4
```
That's why the bug is triggered on 64bit archs.  
gint -> glong signed conversion changes the resulting value.  
And that triggers the failure on checking the value to be valid.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
@vanvugt I'm also able to duplicate the really poor performance when dragging windows around with my 1000Hz mouse. I'm on Arch Linux using the following package for mutter:

https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/mutter-781835-workaround

I manually patched gjs-1.54.1 with gjs!236 and it did not help the issue. Reverting this patch !168 did however fix it. The rest of the patches in that Arch package made a noticeable and major improvement, this specific one is the only one that seems to be detrimental to performance out of those.

The CPU spikes / frame drops seem to happen whenever windows are moved on top of each other. It does not appear to be triggered by window snapping as it happens even if you move it on top of the center of another window far away from window borders.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
Ok, that sounds reasonable that this is a separate issue and that this MR is indeed not the root cause - however I would still suggest that this separate issue is a blocker for a stable 3.32 release containing this patch as it is a *huge* noticeable regression for owners of 1000Hz mice. 

Just a note, many modern gaming mice (Logitech G, Zowie, Steelseries) default to 1000Hz out of the box. This won't just impact a few obscure users who are tuning a sysfs variable or something. My Logitech for example defaults to 1000Hz when plugged in and I **cannot** change to 125Hz without using the Windows driver to put it into a battery saving mode. And while you are correct that it isn't useful to have 1000Hz in GNOME, it *is* useful in games that can run faster on 144/240Hz displays in fullscreen and the user experience of having to toggle your mouse polling rate back and forth to play games or have a good desktop experience is not a good one.

I may need to record a video of the difference to make it clear how big of a regression this is, but without this patch but with the others in that PKGBUILD set Gnome-shell is smoother than I've ever seen it, and with this patch added in (even with gjs!236 included) there are literally half-second pauses where the screen completely stops updating due to the CPU load spike.

Relevant specs: AMD Ryzen 1700 @ 3.9GHz & Nvidia RTX 2080 tested with 410.66 and 410.57 drivers

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
Still seems pretty bad to me. I already had the first two, added 3 and 4 though. Just a clarification the cursor's movement itself is fine, it seems to be moving around at normal speed, but the windows behind the cursor being dragged are much, much slower than without !168 - even if there's only one window on screen at the time.

It does seem to scale by how many windows are opened though, the more opened windows (even if on other workspaces) the slower.

events.target_title: WIP: clutter: Deliver events sooner when possible

note.body:
Same problems, any time 168 is in the performance of dragging windows around (even on otherwise-empty workspaces) tanks. It does seem to be worse the larger the window is, and as you said the cursor itself is updating nice and fast, it's just the window itself that is very slow and lags behind the cursor. 

Looking at htop while doing this, my Xorg process is above 90% CPU with gnome-shell at around the mid 30's. Without !168 my Xorg process stays under 80%, but still is pretty high, and gnome-shell is in the mid 20's, so about a 10% CPU core increase to both. Is it possible this only impacts Nvidia users (just thinking out loud as the primary thread hitting 100% is Xorg, not gnome-shell)?

Visually it's a much bigger difference than those numbers would indicate though, as without !168 it looks like it's completely locked to my 144Hz display with extremely rare frame drops, very similar to Windows 10 on the same system. With !168, it's probably dropping 80% or more of the frames as if I move my mouse quickly while dragging a window it jumps many pixels per update.

Regarding !270 specifically I don't notice a difference with or without it, I'll leave that in my build for now as it's probably helping.

But I had a look at the Network via Wireshark, and you can see clearly the difference between cp and Nautilus/gio copy:
CP
![CP](/uploads/600b675ca1539a7d7d857506e41fe763/CP.png)
Nautilus
![Nautilus](/uploads/7fbe36ec3a7a82e15d299b443702c9a9/Nautilus.png)

events.target_title: Upload Speed over wifi to cifs mounted samba share very slow

note.body:
looked at the process more in detail: 
the problem is that nautilus just asks for 4096 chunks to write, then asks again etc. - while cp asks in the smb write request packet for 131072 (in my case).

So I'm not an expert on SMB - but the ratio is 32:1 - this is the main difference, maybe you can report that to the gio copy guys

events.target_title: Exporting to WebP with lossless enabled on transparent files produces very ugly files that do not open in GIMP

note.body:
Hi,

an update: seems the problem is within exiv2, used for muxing the XMP/EXIF metadata into the webp file.

-> proposed fix here: https://github.com/Exiv2/exiv2/pull/559

skal/

events.target_title: Exporting to WebP with lossless enabled on transparent files produces very ugly files that do not open in GIMP

note.body:
So, the problem is that this optimization is somewhat useful for Renderers like Chrome, that take advantage of the fact that alpha=255 always to avoid the premultiply operation.

If we skip this validation (and hence not use the possibly-wrong hypothesis that alpha=255 when the bit is off), we might do a lot of extra work to 'premultiply' samples that don't need to.

'webpinfo' correctly report that the file is invalid, note.

Agreed, these broken files generated by exiv2 are already in the wild, but i'd like not to fix the demuxing and instead warn the hard way that these files are problematic.

Opinion?

skal/

(pull request merged, btw)
(btw2: Gimp should use libwebmux to incorporate EXIF or XMP, if possible. The files are already re-muxed for ICC, so adding XMP / EXIF on top wouldn't be difficult).

However, it may well be that the implementation of GEGL in the newer [AppImage versions](https://github.com/aferrero2707/gimp-appimage/releases/tag/continuous) of GIMP is responsible. In the [pixel.us](https://discuss.pixls.us/t/how-to-use-high-pass-filter-in-gimp-2-10-10/12103/14?u=s7habo) discussion about this problem, the maintainer says that he used "GEGL git HEAD" for the release builds. 

Also in the [AppImage with GEGL 0.4.14](https://discuss.pixls.us/t/how-to-use-high-pass-filter-in-gimp-2-10-10/12103/18?u=s7habo), which he built in for testing purposes, problem persists. 


I suggest to wait until he answers again before any conclusions can be made.

note.body:
I found a solution to get a working starter without using terminal (except once for installation).
Open the terminal and type

~$ sudo nano /usr/share/applications/ocrfeeder.desktop

then change the following line

Exec=ocrfeeder -i %f                     into

Exec=/usr/bin/./ocrfeeder &/dev/null

Then save and close the editor. Such all error messages (&) are directed to "Nirwana" and OCRFeeder is being opened normally. 

If wanted you can copy the /usr/share/applications/ocrfeeder.desktop file to desktop. Do not change anything at the corresponding starter in the main menu. Even if e.g. menulibre or alacarte means it would have found a "defective" .desktop file in /usr/share/applications the menu-/dock-/etc.-item works well without any change.

Tested with Ubuntu 18.04 LTS

note.body:
sorry about that, the breakage was unintentional.
As written in the cu2qu README, a C compiler is optional for installing cu2qu module.
The problem was: the setup.py was unconditionally calling the bdist_wheel command when compilation fails (e.g. because you have no C compiler available) in order to mark the resulting wheel as pure-python (i.e. not containing any native module); however the bdist_wheel command is only available when the `wheel` module is installed in your environment. Which is almost always the case: e.g. virtualenv always installs pip setuptools _and_ wheel modules in every new environment, but it's true that the python3 venv module does not (only pip and setuptools are installed by default in there).
Another way to fix this issue on your end would have been to upgrade pip >= 10, so that it supports reading the build requirements from the pyproject.toml file (see PEP 517 and 518). The wheel module is listed in there, so it would have been pulled in by pip automatically, but only installed temporarily while building a wheel from sdist.

Anyway, to cut the long story short, I've fixed the issue (made bdist_wheel optional), so you should be able to instal the next cu2qu release without issues. 
I'll cut a release now.

https://github.com/googlei18n/cu2qu/issues/157

note.body: @pgriffis: Correct me if I'm wrong but I think the part WRT simultaneous connections is covered by the timer with 300 ms (by default) timeout. Moreover the addresses are sorted once they're all enumerated so it doesn't matter when they come as long as the enumeration isn't marked finished, no?

events.target_title: libsoup needs a happy-eyeballs IPv6-IPv4 fallback implementation

note.body:
Also:
"Starting a new connection attempt does not affect previous
 attempts, as multiple connection attempts may occur in parallel.
 Once one of the connection attempts succeeds (generally when the TCP
 handshake completes), all other connections attempts that have not
 yet succeeded SHOULD be canceled."
suggests IMO there should be multiple attempts ongoing but just not fired all at once. Time out on one attempt IMO shouldn't cancel it but simply try starting  a new connection to the next address and pick the winner once one is finished. I only had a quick look at the branch but I saw a socket timeout property is used there which I think will cause the attempt to break on timeout, right?

events.target_title: libsoup needs a happy-eyeballs IPv6-IPv4 fallback implementation

note.body: Yes, but sorting after the enumerator finished is a part of the patch. See arrange_attempts()

events.target_title: libsoup needs a happy-eyeballs IPv6-IPv4 fallback implementation

note.body:
>  It only gets one value at a time though right?, it doesn't have the full list as the enumerator does. If you artificially query the enumerator to end too quickly you miss on later async additions.

Not really. It gets all the values from the enumerator by calling it over and over again until its finish() returns no address. At that point it has all addresses from the enumerator gathered (no connection attempt made so far). Once the enumerator doesn't return more addresses, the one retrieved are sorted and connection attempts stage starts

events.target_title: libsoup needs a happy-eyeballs IPv6-IPv4 fallback implementation

note.body: Right. Now I get what you meant. This DNS part is something I didn't look at for my purposes. Let's get back to this on Mon (it's Fri evening for me). It seems I'd need to wait for your part to be finished in order to incorporate it into my patch, is that right?

events.target_title: libsoup needs a happy-eyeballs IPv6-IPv4 fallback implementation

note.body: I agree. Our approaches need to be combined. Being able to rely on the enumerator returning entries in a proper order and knowing things may change in it in the meanwhile should result in enumerate()->connect() being called in the client for every connection attempt (as opposed to enumerate()->enumerate()->...->enumerate()->connect()->... I came up with due to ignoring DNS part).

I wonder what exactly the prefix is about in: 

[`meson build --prefix /home/benoit/gnome`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-system-monitor/blob/master/HACKING#L4)
I originally set the prefix to `/home/da/git/build_gnome-system-monitor` but the directory remained empty and I found the built files in `/home/da/git/gnome-system-monitor/build` so I tried this instead but to no avail.

Edit: Symlink works, still don't know what went wrong in the first place. Do I need to fill the --prefix directory with anything?

events.target_title: network-cc-panel does network rescan and shows: found duplicate: <SSID>  over and over, constant high CPU

note.body:
I had a little free time so dug into this a little more.  I'm seeing the endless looping coming from "notify" signals continuously firing on the access point objects registered from nm_device_wifi_connect_access_point.

Note that each periodic scan will still block the UI thread for a couple of seconds, but by just taking an axe to the code and removing the call to signup for notify events then the ui becomes usable (although perhaps doesn't notice when an AP actually changes its info)

events.target_title: workspace.get_neighbor() no longer works with LEFT and RIGHT directions

note.body:
@fmuellner you can download the patch and see it's content in any text editor. Here is the content of abeve patch:

```
From 86a719cc78149b7db189ff7e5d1f16418d257e9e Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Ron Yorston <rmy@pobox.com>
Date: Tue, 2 Oct 2018 12:47:05 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] Allow workspace layout to be overridden

meta_workspace_manager_override_workspace_layout is implemented by
calling meta_workspace_manager_update_workspace_layout which
respects the workspace_layout_overridden flag.  After the first call
to meta_workspace_manager_override_workspace_layout all subsequent
calls fail silently.

Reset workspace_layout_overridden to FALSE before calling
meta_workspace_manager_update_workspace_layout.

Signed-off-by: Ron Yorston <rmy@pobox.com>
---
 src/core/meta-workspace-manager.c | 2 ++
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+)

diff --git a/src/core/meta-workspace-manager.c b/src/core/meta-workspace-manager.c
index 2670f4938..abc819db0 100644
--- a/src/core/meta-workspace-manager.c
+++ b/src/core/meta-workspace-manager.c
@@ -496,6 +496,8 @@ meta_workspace_manager_override_workspace_layout (MetaWorkspaceManager *workspac
                                                   int                   n_rows,
                                                   int                   n_columns)
 {
+  workspace_manager->workspace_layout_overridden = FALSE;
+
   meta_workspace_manager_update_workspace_layout (workspace_manager,
                                                   starting_corner,
                                                   vertical_layout,
-- 
2.17.1
```

It was a bit disappointing to get bit by this, so hopefully this video and my investigation will help so that others won't be. Thanks for evince and rock on! 👍

events.target_title: Error dialog is not shown when rename fails

note.body:
I restart the computer and enter `nautilus --quit` in command line.But this time when I hit the rename bottom it freezes and exit to `gdb>` automatically. Here are the new log I got.   

events.target_title: Scanner not detected (Ubuntu / Canon LiDE 110)

note.body:
I have the same problem. Since about one month I cannot scan anymore using flatpak, having changed nothing but applying system (debian testing) updates. When I go to preferences, the scanner is not detected.

Now, when i try to debug the issue by launching saned manually with debug enabled:

    $ systemctl stop saned.socket
    $ saned -d128

the scanner is properly detected by paperwork! [and scanning works]

If I am reading correctly saned code, the ability to start saned with systemd and -d flag was added with [this commit](https://gitlab.com/sane-project/backends/commit/5288dd5f61b32da2f4bc18950c247dc3b6e1579d).

events.target_title: Scanner not detected (Ubuntu / Canon LiDE 110)

note.body:
OK I think I spotted the issue. In my case, it seems that the ``saned`` user does not have rights on my USB scanner (Canon LiDE 700F); as I have results when running saned as root but not as saned user.

Here is my test:

    $ sudo systemctl stop saned.socket
    $ sudo /usr/sbin/saned -d 128
    $ flatpak run --command=scanimage work.openpaper.Paperwork -L
    device `net:127.0.0.1:genesys:libusb:003:014' is a Canon LiDE 700F flatbed scanner

    $ sudo -u saned /usr/sbin/saned -d 128
    $ flatpak run --command=scanimage work.openpaper.Paperwork -L

    No scanners were identified. [...]

Now I think that the /lib/udev/rules.d/60-libsane.rules file should contain the line near the end

    ENV{libsane_matched}=="yes", RUN+="/bin/setfacl -m g:scanner:rw $env{DEVNAME}"

but it does not. And indeed, if i run the setfacl command manually on my device file, it works with user saned... and systemd.

Seems there is definitely an issue with debian package: I opened the issue https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=918358

events.target_title: image cropping does not work depending on... gtk theme.
Scanner not detected (Ubuntu / Canon LiDE 110)

note.body:
Until this is fixed in debian, I use the following workaround:

* create an /etc/udev/rules.d/99-libsane.rules
* fill it with
  
   ```
   ENV{libsane_matched}=="yes", RUN+="/bin/setfacl -m g:scanner:rw $env{DEVNAME}"
   ```
* reboot.

Now i can scan again from flatpak paperwork! ;)

note.body:
Your code is good.

I'm a bit annoyed to replace fpos_t by a long because vala doesn't support this type while this affect all languages. We have to rewrite the vala parser in C to avoid this limitation which is quite some work. Using a long limit the size of the source file to 2GB on a 32 bits OS, it's a regression but it's a small one. I agree that it could be the best solution.

Then, if we use a long, I think it could be better to change the type of the filePosition attribute to long in the sInputFile structure too.

What do you think?

As I understand it, XF86Back is for keyboards that have additional navigation buttons. I used xev and pressed back on my mouse, and the only event generated was press and release of button 8.

Potentially I could use xdotool to simulate an XF86Back if button 8 is pressed over lollypop, but that wasn't necessary for Firefox (for example), so I thought this might be the way to go.

I will try to find their code that handles mouse-based history navigation and see if I find anything.

events.target_title: All tool buttons are shown as disabled

note.body:
I fell into this trap as well, and I imagine that I am not the only one.  I prefer a lighter theme, so I chose one that is different from the default, but I did not notice that there are also themes for icons.  I only found the solution through searching the bugtracker (for closed issues).

Couldn't a warning be shown when the user selects an ui theme and an icon theme that are obviously incompatible?

events.target_title: All tool buttons are shown as disabled

note.body:
:-) Oh, that's actually pretty easy, since Gimp is an image processing program!
Just create an image of the toolbox icons on their background with the selected themes.  Now fire up the histogram window, select "luminance" and "show values in perceptual space" and consult the value "std dev" that is displayed at the bottom of the window.  I'm sure that this can be scripted quite easily inside Gimp.  Here are some example values that I get on my machine:

* UI theme "Dark", icon theme "Symbolic": 0.161
* UI theme "Gray", icon theme "Symbolic": 0.096
* UI theme "Light", icon theme "Symbolic": 0.040
* UI theme "Light", icon theme "Color": 0.184
* UI theme "System (pretty light on my machine)", icon theme "Color": 0.210
* UI theme "System", icon theme "Symbolic-Inverted": 0.249

I'm confident that this simple metric is more than sufficient for this purpose.  I would suggest to warn when std dev is below 0.09, say.  One could of course be more pedantic and compute the std dev for each icon and take the minimum of that, but this should not be necessary for coherent icon themes.

-------

When writing the previous comment I had something simpler in mind: storing the compatibilities instead of computing them.  On my system (Debian testing), there are four themes of each kind, thus only 16 combinations.  It would be sufficient to store compatibility for the themes that are bundled with Gimp, or even only against the default ones.

An even simpler solution would be to use an icon theme by default that is compatible with both dark and light UI themes.

-------

I really do believe that this is a real problem and *some* solution should be found.  A significant fraction of Gimp users (1/4, say) will switch the UI theme to something light:  After all, light themes have been and still are the standard for windowed enviroments since their inception in the 1980s and there are objective reasons for that.  Now let's assume that 1/2 of these users are as dumb as me.  This will leave 1/8 of Gimp users with an unusable installation.

note.body:
Hey, same problem here with Arch. I've just performed a system upgrade and a reboot but the problem remains.

With [this document](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.72.5396&rep=rep1&type=pdf) for instance. Pick any page, screw around with the view: zoom in and out, scroll up and down, and strange things will begin to appear.

It also affects other documents :\

```
$ uname -a
Linux etak 5.2.13-arch1-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Sep 6 17:52:33 UTC 2019 x86_64 GNU/Linux

$ evince --version
GNOME Document Viewer 3.32.0
```

My observation is that zooming in or out one step always fixes the rendering, but the problem is still there if you zoom back to original level.

What could be causing the problem? What kind of additional information could you need?

Thank you for support :)
